article.title: High-gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism: results from a space experiment
funding: National Aeronautics and Space Administration grants NNX10AP91G, NNH18ZHA004C, and 80NSSC17K0344
article.abstract: Directing plant growth in weightlessness requires understanding the processes that establish plant orientation and how to manipulate them.

sections.introduction: The perception of the gravity stimulus and the involvement of amyloplasts have long been the focus of plant biology because of the cryptic nature of essential steps in the response of a biological system to physical stimuli such as gravity.
sections.methods: Brassica rapa, var. rapa seeds were commercially sourced. No approvals were required for the study, which complied with all relevant regulations.
sections.results: Exposure to HGMF induced curvature. However, substantial curvature occurred in both presence and absence of magnetic gradients.
sections.discussion: The comparison of space-grown or static ground control seedlings exposed to HGMF with seedlings grown in the non-magnetic field chamber shows strong correspondence between the two conditions.

article.insights_summary: The data show that plants perceive weightlessness, and that their metabolism adjusts to microgravity and mechanostimulation.
article.acknowledgments: This work was supported by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration grants NNX10AP91G, NNH18ZHA004C, and 80NSSC17K0344.
